refnamediv.refpurpose: variable number of arguments in an input argument list

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: A function whose last input argument is varargin can be called with more input arguments than indicated in the input argument list. The calling arguments passed form varargin keyword onwards may then be retrieved within the function in a list named varargin.

Suppose that varargin keyword is the n-th argument of the formal input argument list, then if the function is called with less than n-1 input arguments the varargin list is not defined, if the function is called with n-1 arguments then varargin list is an empty list.
function y = ex(varargin) may be called with any number of input arguments. Within function ex input arguments may be retrieved in varargin(i), i=1:length(varargin).
If it is not the last input argument of a function, varargin is a normal input argument name with no special meaning.
The total number of actual input arguments is given by argn(2).

refsection.title: Remark
refsection.para: Named argument syntax like foo(...,key=value) is incompatible with the use of varargin. The reason is that the names (i.e. keys) associated with values are not stored in the varargin list. Consider for instance:
Result is the same, but the arguments were inverted.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.programlisting:
function exampl(a,varargin) [lhs,rhs]=argn(0) if rhs>=1 then disp(varargin) end endfunction
exampl(1) exampl() exampl(1,2,3) l=list('a',%s,%t); exampl(1,l(2:3))
